title: Do not use term "associated function" in suggestions for "no method named ..." error

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-confusing
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error that should be reworked

labels.name: D-papercut
labels.description: Diagnostic error that needs small tweaks

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.

If you cannot produce a minimal reproduction case (something that would work in
isolation), please provide the steps or even link to a repository that causes
the problematic output to occur.
-->

Given the following code: <!-- Please provide a link to play.rust-lang.org -->

```rust
struct A;

impl A {
    fn foo(&self) {
    }
}
fn main() {
    A.food()
}
```

The current output is:

```
error[E0599]: no method named `food` found for struct `A` in the current scope
 --> src/main.rs:8:7
  |
1 | struct A;
  | --------- method `food` not found for this
...
8 |     A.food()
  |       ^^^^ help: there is an associated function with a similar name: `foo`

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0599`.
```

<!-- The following is not always necessary. -->
Ideally the output should look like:

```
error[E0599]: no method named `food` found for struct `A` in the current scope
 --> src/main.rs:8:7
  |
1 | struct A;
  | --------- method `food` not found for this
...
8 |     A.food()
  |       ^^^^ help: there is a method with a similar name: `foo`

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0599`.
```

<!--
If the problem is not self-explanatory, please provide a rationale for the
change.
-->

I just spent a few hours not realizing I had a typo in the name because I was focussed on the method vs. associated function part of the error instead of realizing I was just missing a letter in the method name. Obviously the terminology is fine if there truly is nothing with a self, &self,... parameter but if the suggestion does have one it should be called a method in the suggestions.

<!--
If dramatically different output is caused by small changes, consider also
adding them here.

If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions. The output might also be
different depending on the Edition.
-->


<!-- TRIAGEBOT_START -->

<!-- TRIAGEBOT_ASSIGN_START -->

<!-- TRIAGEBOT_ASSIGN_DATA_START$${"user":"lyming2007"}$$TRIAGEBOT_ASSIGN_DATA_END -->

<!-- TRIAGEBOT_ASSIGN_END -->
<!-- TRIAGEBOT_END -->
